awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: AGEP Transformation Alliance: CIRTL AGEP - Improved Academic Climate for STEM Dissertators and Postdocs to Increase Interest in Faculty Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
Iowa State University, Boston University, Cornell University, Howard University, Michigan State University, Northwestern University, University of Buffalo, University of Georgia, University of Maryland College Park, and University of Texas at Arlington will collaborate to develop, build and test the impact of a model of a "networked improvement community" focused on improving dissertator experiences at a variety of institutions with the goal of reducing the effect of negative climate on interest in faculty careers. The project was submitted in response to the NSF's Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program solicitation (NSF 16-552). The AGEP program seeks to advance knowledge about models to improve pathways to the professoriate and success of historically underrepresented minority (URM) students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty in specific STEM disciplines and/or STEM education research fields. AGEP Transformation Alliances develop or replicate/reproduce, implement and study, via integrated educational/social science research, models to transform the dissertator phase of doctoral education, postdoctoral training and/or faculty advancement, and the transitions within and across the pathway levels, of URMs in STEM and/or STEM education research careers.

The project includes activities to address faculty and postdoc behavior and knowledge about mentoring, advising, and mitigating implicit bias and micro-aggressions as well as activities to support dissertators through workshops similar to faculty workshops, building cohorts and peer mentoring. A super-structure of the ten alliance members will work together to produce and share information and disseminate change more broadly. Evaluation will be done by a team from Michigan State University led by Dr. Marilyn Amey. Integrated research is built into the collaborative process as the community will go through four plan-do-study-act cycles to share information about interventions, plan improvements, coordinate evaluation, and spread effective interventions through first the collaboration and then disseminate them to the 46 institution CIRTL network. Research questions will address 1) student descriptions of engagement with their departments and disciplines, 2) which experiences and relationships are most influential in strengthening students' interest in faculty careers, and 3) how peers and external supports influence sense of community for dissertators. Along with testing the impact of a variety of interventions at nine institutions on the transition from dissertators to faculty and on the climate experienced by dissertators, the project will evaluate the impact of the network itself through a social network analysis, semi-structured interviews, and qualitative analysis of local and community meeting records.

por.por_cntn:
The Networked Improvement Community's (NIC) social science researchers focused on improving dissertator experiences with the goal of creating a more inclusive environment for graduate students. In an environment that is welcoming and where differences are valued, graduate students and postdocs can do their best work and use their different perspectives to help solve today’s largest challenges. We examined the role that Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) graduate students play in understanding and influencing departmental climates, catalysts of change, and mentoring/advising supplements for faculty. The NIC’s hypothesis was that if climate is improved in graduate education, then the number of underrepresented graduate students and postdocs interested in and prepared for faculty careers will increase. An inclusive research environment is one where all graduate students and postdocs feel they belong and are recognized for their contributions. This aligned powerfully with the mission of each NIC university, namely to ensure all students can succeed as scholars and human beings. Achieving an inclusive climate requires changes at the individual- (e.g., faculty) and group-level (department/graduate peers), and must entail organizational learning so that the improvements are not isolated and disconnected. 

 

At the University of Maryland, our grant activity investigated how faculty, administrators, and postdocs described problems that underlie a negative racial climate. We conducted a series of focus groups to better understand the experiences of graduate students. We found that focus group participants aimed to evade the increased labor (e.g., service committees and workshops) and microaggressions associated with racism and White supremacy but faced a conundrum realizing that increased labor is often an unintended consequence of creating institutional change. The amplified labor for graduate students and faculty champions of diversity, equity, and inclusion (who were often racial-minority faculty) often leads to burnout due to change efforts with little support.

 

Throughout the development of the CIRTL AGEP NIC, we have been implementing changes on our campus to make progress on project goals that focus on: faculty member attitudes and behaviors to be more inclusive and equitable; improving the quality and equity of admissions processes, advising, and mentoring of graduate students; and developing transparent databases about disparities. Accordingly, we held a series of professional development and research workshops geared at preparing graduate students for faculty careers and assisting them with navigating the counters and stresses of a racialized society. 

The legacy of AGEP-funded activities at the University of Maryland are as follows:

●      Within the graduate enterprise, an understanding that without collaboration we cannot put an end to racism and inequality. Many lasting partnerships were a result of or inspired by AGEP activities.

●      The mental health of graduate students/postdocs impacts all of us within an institution. One of the outcomes of AGEP interventions was the proposal of a new position within the Graduate School: the Graduate Academic Counselor position, responsible for not only supporting the well-being of graduate students/postdocs but providing programming focused on mental health and self-care. [Position was filled January 2020.]

●      Transformative programming - focused on individuals, departments/programs, and systems.

●      Retention of URM doctoral students within their programs and assistance with obtaining a tenure-track position or research position in their desired field.

There are many anecdotal instances where an AGEP-funded program, course, mentoring experience, or conversation positively altered a student’s doctoral path. We are confident that the impact of this AGEP CIRTL funding will influence organizational processes, mentoring, research collaborations, and career success.
